name: Milne, Sen Christine
text:
asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 19 February 2008:
Original answer to question on notice No. 287, Senate Official Hansard, 13 May 2008, page 1668.
With reference to the series of bushfires that began burning on or about 6 December 2006 on the east coast of Tasmania, seriously damaging a number of areas, especially the Four Mile Creek district:1

When did the AARC first meet; and (b) (i) how often did it meet, (ii) on what dates, and (iii) who attended.
Can a breakdown be provided of funds expended by the AARC; if not, why not.

1 Please note this response is in addition to Sub No: 12-48

name: Wong, Sen Penny
text:
—The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator’s question:
The AARC first met on 9 January 2007.
(b)(i)     The AARC met twelve times throughout the calendar year.
The AARC met twelve times throughout the calendar year.
(ii)     The AARC met on 9 January 2007; 18 January 2007; 8 February 2007; 22 February 2007; 8 March 2007; 29 March 2007; 26 April 2007; 7 June 2007; 5 July 2007; 2 August 2007; 25 September 2007 and 14 December 2007.
(iii)    Representation at some or all of the AARC meetings was as follows:
Tasmanian Government Department of Health and Human Services; the Australian Red Cross; Break O’Day Council; (the former) Australian Government Department of Transport and Regional Services; Australian Government Department of Families, Community Services and Indigenous Affairs; St Helen’s Police; State Emergency Services; Tasmanian Government Department of Premier and Cabinet; South Australia’s State Recovery Office; Local Recovery Coordinator for Eyre Peninsula Bushfires; a community representative; Department of Families, Housing, Community Services and Indigenous Affairs; and the Disaster Recovery Coordinator.
The following link, the Report on the Tasmanian East Coast Fires, (Appendix 1) provides a list of projects funded using the Community Recovery Funds. Appendix 4 of the Report notes the commitment of funding.
http://www.bodc.tas.gov.au/webdata/resources/files/East_Coast_Fires_Recovery_Final_Report_signed.pdf
The administration of these funds is not yet complete and is subject to acquittal through an independent audit process.

The acquittal process with regard to the administration of the Tasmanian East Coast Bushfire Community Recovery Fund expenditure is provided below.

 

The Affected Area Recovery Committee’s (the Committee) Terms of Reference require the Committee to report to the Tasmanian Government.
The Tasmanian Government, through its Department of Finance and Treasury, will submit a consolidated Natural Disaster Relief and Recovery Arrangements (NDRRA) claim for total expenditure incurred in the relevant financial year/s on all eligible natural disaster events.
A requirement for the provision of Australian Government assistance under the NDRRA (including community recovery funds) is that where a state submits a claim for financial reimbursement, they must submit an audited financial statement in support of that claim within six months after the end of the financial year in which the claim was made.
With regard to all NDRRA eligible Tasmanian expenditure, the acquittal process will undertaken by the Tasmanian Audit Office.
The audit process is due for completion by 31 December 2009.
